Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Portable Water Purification Device for the Removal of Ions and Heavy Metals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Owing to drinking water issues in some cities and rural remote areas, this I-Corps team has designed a portable, simple, and effective device to purify drinking water to meet the essential standards. The proposed device can remove heavy metals, such as lead, copper, arsenic, and other elements from tap water that can cause serious health issues. Lead containing pipes in old water distribution systems and old buildings can introduce lead to the tap water as seen in the ongoing water crisis case in Flint, MI. The lead poisoning is uncompromised and it may have lifelong consequences on Flint children. Lead may cause severe consequences, such as dropping the IQ and behavioral abnormalities with multi-generational impacts. In such cases in urban areas, the drinking water needs to be treated in household levels since it may take a long time to have the problem fixed by the administrative organizations and regulators. The proposed device can be utilized in these conditions to purify the drinking water and eliminate the undesired elements from water. The device can also be distributed in cities where residents prefer to purchase bottled water or use household water treatment systems to ensure that there will not be any long-term effects of undesired elements in water. Additionally, the device can be used for drinking water purification in rural areas where residents often suffer from unavailability of safe drinkable water. Through the NSF I-Corps program, the team intends to prove the value proposition of the technology and evaluate prospective clients.

The goal of this project is building a new portable efficient drinking water purification device for removal of heavy metals and other ions from water. The proposed device, utilizes not only physical adsorption approach, which is the main heavy metal removal method in common heavy metal removal filters, but also the electrical force to enhance the ion removal process. In this device, the applied electrical field triggers the electro-migration of the ions toward electrodes and then the ions are physically adsorbed on the adsorbent surface. Additionally, the mixing feature of the device enhances the overall mass transfer rate in the process. The adsorbent can be regenerated effectively or replaced after a period of functioning. Therefore, the operating cost of this new device will be much lower than common membrane-based technologies and its efficiency is higher than the adsorption-based water treatment filters. The device will be made in two models, one for urban areas, which can utilize AC electricity and has mixing capability with higher efficiency, and the other for use in off-grid and rural areas, which is simpler and can be energized using batteries. Therefore, the scope of the potential customers will be wider and the device's application will not be limited to a specific condition due to its effective and quick removal of heavy metals and other common ionic pollutants in water. The experience during the I-Corps program will help the team develop a business and commercialize a needed product.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Considering global drinking water scarcity and water pollution problems in the United States and around the world, our group designed a portable water purification device which could be used in urban as well as rural remote areas. Our designed potable water purification device has both capability of water desalination and heavy metals removal. Our proposed system has higher efficiency in removal of heavy metals compared to the available products in the market. Additionally, it does not need any installation and its capital cost is expected to be lower than the competitors. The group participated in NSF I-Corps spring 2016 cohort in Georgia Institute of Technology, through which we could identify the available market to our product. Through the group's attendance in training workshops and taught courses, the group members were trained in fundamentals of entrepreneurship, customer discovery, business model development, weekly finding presentations and discussion, and conducted more than 110 customer discovery interviews.

Based on the findings during the customer discovery process, the group members proposed different customer segments, such as residents in urban areas with drinking water quality concerns, residents in remote off-grid rural areas, backpackers, and boat runners in the United States. Figure 1 and 2 show the locations where the customer discovery was conducted, while Figure 3 and 4 illustrate the diversity of proposed customer segments.

Through the customer discovery, it was found that the above-mentioned proposed customer segments in the United States (Figure 3) are not interested in our water purification system due to the following reasons:

  1. Most of people use bottled water as an easy solution for issues related to tap water;
  2. Some people believe that the available products in the market meet their needs and are not interested in any other product; and,
  3. There is a good trust in the quality of city water, especially in Northern and North-eastern cities of the United States, but the cities with media-covered drinking water problems, such as Flint, MI.

These findings through the customer discovery led us to our new potential customer segments in developing countries, such as Bangladesh and India. Based on our findings, our product's value proposition can meet the needs of the residents of these countries better than the other available products due to its capability in removing salinity and heavy metals. However, one of the factors to be considered is the cost of final product in the local markets.

Finally, the main learning outcome for the team members from the customer discovery process, online courses, interactions with the instructors and other teams was that the customer discovery is the first and most crucial step that should be carefully conducted before detailed product development and putting efforts for commercialization. Although the developed technologies in the lab may seem very attractive to the inventors and scientist in the academic world, this attraction does not guarantee a successful market for such technologies. However, the customer discovery step can lead the entrepreneurs in designing and introduction of a product that the potential customers cannot wait to have it. Moreover, developing the business model in this step has helped our entrepreneurial leads to look for a feasible solution for having a successful product development, commercialization, and marketing.
